ratings.question_text: Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:

narratives.question_text: Please list any other mode(s) of learning, including any combination or variation of the above options.
comments: We would meet once a week for a live class.
None
NA

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned to analyze and appreciate 19th century poetry and to be able to express my thoughts coherently in papers and presentations.

The course provides a very good introduction to the genre of the prose poem in French. The course allowed me to deepen my understanding of French poetry and also to improve my written and spoken French. The papers are a great opportunity to practice close reading.
Improved knowledge of French poetry and advanced skills in French writing style
This course was
Traced the thread of modernity through the lens of the prose poem, as it developed across the 19th and 20th centuries

Improvement in French ability in an academic context, including reading, writing, speaking, and listening. A great course to improve your skills in particular if you wish to improve your French ability in a more formal setting.
Speaking, Writing, and Analysis in the French Language
I learned to read French poetry and to write analytical essays in French.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I wish we had more class time, one class just wasn't enough to cover all the wonderful material.
The chronology of the course was intuitive

Strengths: very flexible style that allowed for students to be creative and interact freely with the texts. The selected texts were all amazing and the discussion was very friendly and encouraging while still presenting an intellectual challenge.
Weaknesses: none

Strengths: Professor Connolly is great--one of the most encouraging and kind professors i've had! Reading list is great survey of major works of prose poetry.
Weaknesses: The structure of the seminar meetings--presentation, mini-lecture, individual discussion in breakout rooms, and regrouping--got a bit repetitive over time, though. I think the course would benefit from some more variation in structure.

Pretty much everything was great; the one weakness is that at times there was too much reading. The books are great, but the few times where we were asked to read 200+ pages of French poetry in a week was a bit much. However, to Professor Connolly's credit, nothing about the class is structured to punish you for not reading enough, as long as you've read a decent amount. So he is likely aware of this fact.
I thought this course was great and conducted as well as possible for the Zoom era

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The lecture was great, mostly due to the professor. He also hosted office hours once a week which was really helpful. The time difference however (since I find myself on the West Coast) was hard, but it had to be done especially among these times.
Breakout rooms to discuss poems and report back worked well
The virtual seminar format was quite engaging (almost the same as an in-person one would've been, I think), perhaps due in part to the small size of the class.
The small-class format really added to the seminar experience: every one had a chance to participate.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would DEFINITELY recommend this course to any student interested in 19th century literature and especially French literature and poetry. The material is absolutely beautiful to read and engage with. You have so much support from the professor to do well and succeed in all your papers. The small size of the section really helped to have a hands on engagement with the books as well as with the professor and your peers. My favorite class at Yale!

I recommend this course to anyone interested in 19th- and 20th-century French literature. Even if you are unsure as to whether you are interested in the prose poem in particular, I still highly recommend it because you will become familiar with some major figures in modern French literature.
Yes, you gain proficiency in important French poetry and writing style

Yes I absolutely would! It's a very laid-back course and you don't need to have a background in french literature or poetry to learn and participate actively. The course is also very flexible and you have a lot of freedom on the assignments to add your own interpretation. Overall a great course!
Yes--great course. I don't think prose poetry is necessarily for me, but I still thoroughly enjoyed the course readings and discussions!
Yes! If you have an interest/ need the credit for a major or certificate, Prof Connolly is a great professor and not to be missed.
For a student hoping to improve their literary, historical, and even cultural relationship with the French language, I would most certainly recommend this course.
Yes! But be prepared for a significant amount of dense reading and challenging writing.
